description.narrative:
Civicus was granted funds for a planning phase in March 2019 to convene members and other organizations for consultations and planning for a program (contr ID 13211). Based on this, Civicus, together with Fojo Media Institute and Civil Rights Defenders, undertook a four-month (March – June 2019) consultation and participatory design process with representatives from the media and civil society to explore the potential of a multi-stakeholder consortium. As a result, Civicus has now presented a three-year (2019-2021) program outline to the Embassy with a total budget of 74 100 000 SEK. The appraisal to this contribution has scrutinized the entire three years Program (October 2019 to December 2022), however, the Embassy is set to take a decision and sign an agreement only for 2019 and 2020 (34 MSEK) due to a limited framework for future outstanding commitments. Thus, there will be a cost extension for the remaining period of the project.
The proposed programme intends to address the problem of increasing civic space restrictions in Sub-Saharan Africa that is severely affecting fundamental freedoms and which undermines the health of democracy, respect for human rights, progress of development and struggle for social justice. The programme mainly focuses on building the capacity and resilience of media actors, rights-based civil society organizations and human rights defenders as they are the ones that first and foremost face the brunt of these restrictions. This capacity-building effort is expected to contribute to improved resilience and capabilities at the level of the African regional and national stakeholders to scale up and increase effectiveness of their work.
The program builds on an integrated way of working by a consortium of six civil society, media and human rights defenders specialist Pan-African and international organizations led by Civicus; namely, Civil Rights Defenders, Fojo Media Institute, Hub Afrique, DefendDefenders and Wits Journalism. Four thematically integrated objectives are set: 1) Strengthened advocacy actions that support an enabling environment that promotes human rights, civic and media freedoms 2) Counter-narratives and improved public support for a free and vibrant civil society and media 3) Coalition-building that encourages coordination and joint action, and provides solidarity in the face of attacks and threats 4) Enhanced access to resources that strengthen the ability of civil society and the media to withstand civic space restrictions and achieve their objectives.
The programme targets 19 sub-Sahara Africa countries where civic freedoms are obstructed, but where there is still space to speak out, organize and take action, and where pockets of resistance can be supported through various national, sub-regional and regional actors and initiatives to strengthen human rights and democratic freedoms.

I mars 2019 beviljades Civicus medel för en planeringsfas (contribution ID 13211) med syfte att samla medlemmar och andra organisationer för konsultation och planering för ett program. Baserat på detta genomförde Civicus tillsammans med Fojo Media Institute och Civil Rights Defenders en fyra månaders (mars - juni 2019) konsultation och deltagande designprocess med representanter från media och civilsamhället. Syftet var att utforska vilken potential som fanns för ett konsortium med flera aktörer. Detta resulterade i att Civicus nu har lagt fram ett treårigt (2019–2021) programförslag till ambassaden med en total budget på 74 100 000 SEK. Beredningen inför beslut om insats baserar sig på hela det treåriga programmet (oktober 2019- december 2022). Ambassaden tar i nuläget beslut och tecknar avtal enbart för 2019 och 202 (34 MSEK) givet begränsad bemyndiganderam för kommande år. Tilläggsbeslut planeras därmed för den återstående programperioden.
Det föreslagna programmet avser hantera det minskande medborgerliga utrymme i Afrika söder om Sahara. Det minskande demokratiska utrymmet påverkar grundläggande friheter och undergräver demokratin, respekten för de mänskliga rättigheterna och bromsar framsteg i utveckling och kampen för social rättvisa. Programmet fokuserar främst på att stärka kapacitet och motståndskraft hos medieaktörer, rättighetsbaserade civilsamhällsorganisationer och mänskliga rättighetsförsvarare, eftersom dessa är de som först och främst blir lidande av dessa begränsningar. Denna kapacitetsuppbyggande insats förväntas bidra till förbättrad motståndskraft och kapacitet hos afrikanska regionala och nationella aktörerna för att utöka och stärka effektiviteten i deras arbete.
Programmets struktur bygger på ett integrerat arbetssätt inom ett konsortium bestående av panafrikanska och internationella civilsamhällesorganisationer, mediaaktörer och människorättsförsvararorganisationer under ledning och samordning av Civicus; Civil Rights Defenders, Fojo Media Institute, Hub Afrique, DefendDefenders och Wits Journalism. Fyra tematiskt integrerade mål har formulerats: 1) Förstärkt påverkansarbete för ökat utrymme och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter och medie- och yttrandefrihet, 2) Kontra-narrativ (counter-narratives) och förbättrat offentligt stöd för ett fritt och levande civilsamhälle och media, 3) Koalitionsbyggande som uppmuntrar koordinering och gemensamma insatser, samt som skapar solidaritet i händelse av attacker eller hot, och 4) Förbättrad tillgång till resurser som stärker det civila samhällets och medias förmåga att uthärda restriktioner i det demokratiska utrymmet och för att uppnå sina mål.
Programmet riktar in sig på 19 länder i Afrika söder om Sahara där civila fri- och rättigheter begränsas, men där det fortfarande finns möjlighet att organisera, agera och uttala sig och där motstånd kan stödjas genom olika nationella, sub-regionala och regionala aktörer och initiativ till förmån för demokrati och mänskliga rättigheter.

The overall objective of the program is to strengthen the effectiveness and building the resilience (ability to adapt and transform in order to continue their work) of journalists and other media practitioners and social media producers, human rights defenders and civil society activists and their organisations in relevant countries, which, in a longer-term perspective, will lead towards more democratic and free societies. The overall objective is elaborated through four specific objectives that are designed in a well-integrated manner in terms of thematic area synchronization and stakeholder participation and coordination: 1. Strengthened advocacy actions that support an enabling environment that promotes human rights and civic and media freedoms2. Counter-narratives and improved public support for a free and vibrant civil society and media3. Coalition-building that encourages coordination and joint action, and provides solidarity in the face of attacks and threats4. Enhanced access to resources that strengthen the ability of civil society and the media to withstand civic space restrictions and achieve their objectives Civicus suggests sequencing of results in three phases; short-term, medium and long-term. This program is expected to generalte short-term outcomes (2019-2022) - target stakeholders (i.e. journalists, human rights defenders and civil society activists and organisations in target countries) will have: 1. Improved understanding of their rights and are more enabled to demand/exercise their rights than before;2. Increased direct engagement with decision-makers and institutions at all levels with a view to protecting human rights and democratic and media freedoms; 3. Increased engagement amongst themselves and with other relevant actors (constituencies) that is evidenced through learning, exchange and collective/solidarity actions; and4. Increased access to support and resources that help them to improve the quality and sustainability of their work. Subsequently, Civicus envisages medium (4-5 years) and long-term (beyond 5 years) outcomes as necessary prerequisites to achieve the overall objective of the program; Accordingly, results on medium term include: 1. Improved recognition and protection of human rights and civic and media freedoms in target countries, 2. Increased number of instances of people acting collectively to drive social transformation at all levels; 3. Improved capacity of target stakeholders to sustain their work and deliver on their mandates Long term results include:1. Reduced restrictions on civic space, CSOs and media; 2. Enhanced trust in media/civil society as critical sources of information and champions of accountability; 3. Improved resilience of journalists, human rights defenders and civil society activists (i.e. better equipped to withstand restrictions and challenge actions that undermine human rights and democratic values) in the target countries.

description.narrative:
The CHARM and its stakeholders have not been an exception to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic that has had a drastic impact on civil society around the world. Restrictions on travel and assembly, along with many associated challenges experienced by CHARMs target audiences, have required the consortium to still continue on making significant reformulation and adaptation to its approach and activities. But CHARM has been able to achieve many important results and learn vital lessons to further improve and develop the project implementation. Among the results:
Security training: A year after the Digital Security Training of Trainers (ToT) programme of 2020 organised by CHARM, eight in ten ToT participants have conducted at least one training each and are ready and able to independently conduct trainings on digital security. This demonstrates a change in capacity as participants who attended the digital training are now able to independently deliver similar trainings to their constituents without technical or financial support from CHARM.
Defenders Database: Between 2020 and early 2021, four organisations signed agreements with CHARM to start using and implementing the Defenders Database as a tool in their workflow to document and analyse human rights violations, including trends in violations against human rights defenders. The Defenders Database helps to systematically document human rights issues and helps organisations to analyse trends, produce reports and engage in advocacy.
Coalition-Building: Through CHARMs financial support, local organisations have developed joint activities and strengthened their relationships. For instance, TIKenya partnered with Magamba Network to engage in the 254 COVID-19 Virtual Hackathon from 9th 13th February 2021 to encourage regional collaboration between organizations implementing similar initiatives on tracking utilisation of COVID-19 funds. TI-Kenya engaged 17 (11 male, 6 female) young software developers from six participating teams and four local partnering institutions.?
In general, the programme has displayed a formidable result in building the capacity of CSOs in resource mobilization and advocacy for democratic change and accountability. The program has also successfully contributed in equipping human rights defenders with tools promoting digital and physical security; the media has also benefited from the capacity building effort of the program around investigative journalism, professional journalism and fact checking that has resulted in building of fact check network.
